messages.content:
The following eight short â€œAutumnâ€-titled yuan-drama songs are brief yet push autumn mood and longing to the limit. Listed by period and author for easy reference; each is followed by a one-line cue to its color and feeling.

1. Sky-Clear Sand Â· Autumn Thoughts  
   Ma Zhiyuan  
   Withered vines, old tree, dusk crows; small bridge, running water, homestead; ancient road, west wind, lean horse. Sun slants west: heart-broken man at skyâ€™s edge.  
   Cue: Twenty-eight characters paint â€œautumn dusk of a wanderer,â€ hailed as the ancestor of all autumn laments.

2. Sky-Clear Sand Â· Autumn (also titled simply Autumn)  
   Bai Pu  
   Lonely village, setting sun, fading rose clouds; thin smoke, old tree, cold crows; one wild-goose shadow drops. Blue hills, green waters, white grass, red leaves, yellow flowers.  
   Cue: From bleak to brilliant, a color-soaked autumn diptych.

3. Sky-Clear Sand Â· Autumn  
   Zhu Tingyu  
   Before the court, every phoenix-tree leaf has fallen; by the water, lotus blooms are fully openâ€”sharing the poetâ€™s mood. Frosted leaves leave their branch and fly to me for a red-ink inscription.  
   Cue: Parlor trees versus pond blooms, garden autumnâ€™s solitude and refinement.

4. Great-Virtue Song Â· Autumn  
   Guan Hanqing  
   Wind flutters, rain spits; even the sleep-immortal Chen Tuan could not dozeâ€¦Autumn cicadas finish, cold crickets begin; a fine thin drizzle taps the plantain.  
   Cue: Rain, insect, plantainâ€”each sound a stroke of autumn-night fretwork.

5. Clear-River Refrain Â· Autumn Heart  
   Zhang Kejiu  
   West wind brings word from home ten thousand li, asking my return date. Wild geese cry beneath red-leaf skies; drunk on yellow-flower ground, I dream to the sound of rain on plantain.  
   Cue: West wind, homing goose, yellow chrysanthemum, plantainâ€”every line adds another layer of homesick autumn.

6. Clear-River Refrain Â· Autumn Dwelling  
   Wu Xiyi  
   White geese scatter like autumn snow; clear dew chills the nightâ€¦Star-brimming skyâ€”man asleep.  
   Cue: Geese as snow, dew as frost, a traveler under star-riverâ€”cool, crisp, free.

7. Drunk in East Wind Â· Autumn Scene  
   Lu Zhi  
   On sheer cliff, a withered pine leans upside-down; with falling afterglow, lone wild duck wings levelâ€¦Carry me inside a Xiao-Xiang scroll.  
   Cue: Mountain, water, sunset, duckâ€”cinematic â€œautumn boat on Xiao-Xiang.â€

8. Water-Fairy Â· Night Rain  
   Xu Zaisi  
   One wutong leaf, one drop of autumn; one plantain drip, one grain of sorrowâ€¦all reach the heart.  
   Cue: Night rain counts out ten years of exile and parentsâ€™ whitening hair, leaf by leaf, drop by drop.

Reading tips  
â€¢ Yuan short songs are perfect for a quiet autumn afternoon or lamplight; add a cup of yellow wine or bitter tea and the â€œautumn tasteâ€ deepens.  
â€¢ For more, collect the individual anthologies of Ma Zhiyuan, Bai Pu, and Zhang Kejiuâ€”they wrote the most, and the most typical, autumn pieces.
Summer's Yuan Qu

   â”€â”€Lotus scent for ten li; tie the orchid boat beneath willow shade, spread a bamboo mat, loosen your collar and let your hair down.

3. å¤©å‡€æ²™ Â· å¤  
   ç™½æœ´  
   äº‘æ”¶é›¨è¿‡æ³¢æ·»ï¼Œæ¥¼é«˜æ°´å†·ç“œç”œï¼Œç»¿æ ‘é˜´å‚ç”»æªã€‚çº±å¨è—¤ç°Ÿï¼Œç‰äººç½—æ‰‡è½»ç¼£ã€‚  
   â”€â”€After-summer-shower lake rises; from high balcony taste cold melons; green shade drips along painted eaves; gauze curtains, rattan mat, fair girl waving thin-silk fan.

4. æ¸…æ±Ÿå¼• Â· å¤å¤œå³äº‹  
   å¼ å¯ä¹…  
   é†‰æ¥æ™šé£ç”Ÿç”»å±ï¼Œå°é™¢ç¬¼å‡‰å½±ã€‚æ°´é¢æœˆæ— æ³¢ï¼Œè¡£ä¸Šäº‘çŠ¹å†·ï¼Œå€šé˜‘å¹²æŠŠèŠ±æè½»é—®å½±ã€‚  
   â”€â”€Tipsy at night, a breeze stirs the painted screen; moonlight lies unruffled on water; even my sleeves feel cloud-cool; leaning on the balustrade I ask my own flower-shadow a silent question.

5. æ¸…æ±Ÿå¼• Â· å¤å¤œ  
   å¼ å¯ä¹…  
   çº³å‡‰æ—¶ï¼Œæ³¢æ¶¨æ²™ï¼Œæœˆç…§èŠ™è“‰æ°´ã€‚å±•é²›ç»¡ï¼Œé“ºç»¿èŠœï¼Œä¸€æ•è·é¦™é‡Œã€‚  
   â”€â”€Spread mermaid-silk on green reed-bank, pillow yourself inside lotus fragrance while moonlight floods the water-lilies.

6. æ¸…æ±Ÿå¼• Â· å¤å¤œçº³å‡‰å³å¸­  
   å¼ å¯ä¹…  
   å››æ›´é£ç”Ÿæ°´é™…æ³¢ï¼Œè—•å¶èƒœç½—ç»®ã€‚å‡‰å…¥è±¡ç‰™åºŠï¼Œæœˆè½¬è‘¡è„æ¶ï¼ŒæŠŠäººé—´ç§¯æš‘æ¶ˆé™¤å°½å½’ã€‚  
   â”€â”€Fourth-watch wind skims the waves; lotus leaves outshine silk; coolness slips into the ivory couch while moon drifts across the grape-arbourâ€”every scrap of earthly heat erased.

7. æ°´ä»™å­ Â· ä»²å¤å³äº‹  
   å¾å†æ€  
   ç¬‘å°†çº¢è¢–é®çº¨æ‰‡ï¼Œç»¿é˜´æµ“ã€èŠ³è‰æµ…ï¼Œæ± äº­é¿æš‘å¼€ç¼å®´ã€‚  
   â”€â”€Laughing, a girl in red sleeves hides behind her round silk fan; thick shade, tender grass; in the pool-side pavilion we set out a jade-cold banquet.

8. æ°´ä»™å­ Â· å¤å¤œ  
   ä½šåï¼ˆæ˜é€‰æœ¬æ”¶ï¼‰  
   å†°å£¶å…‰æµ¸çŸ³æ¦´è£™ï¼Œè·æ°”é¦™æµ®ç«¹å¶æ¨½ï¼Œæ»¡å¤©é£éœ²è–„ç½—çº¹ã€‚  
   â”€â”€Crystal moonlight soaks the pomegranate-red skirt; lotus scent steams the bamboo-leaf wine; wind and dew embroider the thin silk night.

How to enjoy  
Read them aloud slowly; each is only 28â€“35 Chinese characters, yet they compress all the stock â€œsummer codesâ€ of Yuan writersâ€”lotus, bamboo mat, moonlit water, silk fan, melon, willow-shaded boatâ€”into a single breath of cool air.

## Data Description

#### `symile_mimic_data.csv`

-  50 columns representing the `itemid` for the 50 labs listed below and containing the earliest lab value recorded within 24 hours of admission.

-  `labs_all_nan`: A binary indicator (0 or 1) that shows whether all lab values in the specified columns are missing ( `1` if all lab values are missing, `0` otherwise).

Further details on the columns can be found in the MIMIC documentation for the labevents table in the MIMIC-IV Hosp module \[9\].

```
# keys are itemids, values are lab names
LABS = {
    "51221": "Hematocrit",
    "51265": "Platelet Count",
    "50912": "Creatinine",
    "50971": "Potassium",
    "51222": "Hemoglobin",
    "51301": "White Blood Cells",
    "51249": "MCHC",
    "51279": "Red Blood Cells",
    "51250": "MCV",
    "51248": "MCH",
    "51277": "RDW",
    "51006": "Urea Nitrogen",
    "50983": "Sodium",
    "50902": "Chloride",
    "50882": "Bicarbonate",
    "50868": "Anion Gap",
    "50931": "Glucose",
    "50960": "Magnesium",
    "50893": "Calcium, Total",
    "50970": "Phosphate",
    "51237": "INR(PT)",
    "51274": "PT",
    "51275": "PTT",
    "51146": "Basophils",
    "51256": "Neutrophils",
    "51254": "Monocytes",
    "51200": "Eosinophils",
    "51244": "Lymphocytes",
    "52172": "RDW-SD",
    "50934": "H",
    "51678": "L",
    "50947": "I",
    "50861": "Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)",
    "50878": "Asparate Aminotransferase (AST)",
    "50813": "Lactate",
    "50863": "Alkaline Phosphatase",
    "50885": "Bilirubin, Total",
    "50820": "pH",
    "50862": "Albumin",
    "50802": "Base Excess",
    "50821": "pO2",
    "50804": "Calculated Total CO2",
    "50818": "pCO2",
    "52075": "Absolute Neutrophil Count",
    "52073": "Absolute Eosinophil Count",
    "52074": "Absolute Monocyte Count",
    "52069": "Absolute Basophil Count",
    "51133": "Absolute Lymphocyte Count",
    "50910": "Creatine Kinase (CK)",
    "52135": "Immature Granulocytes"
}
```

[æ ‡é¢˜]:MIMIC-ivå®˜æ–¹SQLæ¦‚å¿µè¯­å¥æ ‡æ³¨â€”â€”mimic_derivedæ¨¡å—éƒ¨åˆ† ...

```
-- The aim of this query is to pivot entries related to blood gases
-- which were found in LABEVENTS
WITH bg AS
(
select
  -- specimen_id only ever has 1 measurement for each itemid
  -- so, we may simply collapse rows using MAX()
    MAX(subject_id) AS subject_id
  , MAX(hadm_id) AS hadm_id
  , MAX(charttime) AS charttime
  -- specimen_id *may* have different storetimes, so this is taking the latest
  , MAX(storetime) AS storetime
  , le.specimen_id
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 52028 THEN value ELSE NULL END) AS specimen
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50801 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS aado2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50802 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS baseexcess
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50803 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS bicarbonate
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50804 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS totalco2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50805 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS carboxyhemoglobin
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50806 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS chloride
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50808 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS calcium
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50809 and valuenum <= 10000 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS glucose
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50810 and valuenum <= 100 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS hematocrit
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50811 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS hemoglobin
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50813 and valuenum <= 10000 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS lactate
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50814 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS methemoglobin
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50815 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS o2flow
  -- fix a common unit conversion error for fio2
  -- atmospheric o2 is 20.89%, so any value <= 20 is unphysiologic
  -- usually this is a misplaced O2 flow measurement
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50816 THEN
      CASE
        WHEN valuenum > 20 AND valuenum <= 100 THEN valuenum
        WHEN valuenum > 0.2 AND valuenum <= 1.0 THEN valuenum*100.0
      ELSE NULL END
    ELSE NULL END) AS fio2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50817 AND valuenum <= 100 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS so2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50818 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS pco2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50819 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS peep
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50820 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS ph
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50821 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS po2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50822 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS potassium
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50823 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS requiredo2
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50824 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS sodium
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50825 THEN valuenum ELSE NULL END) AS temperature
  , MAX(CASE WHEN itemid = 50807 THEN value ELSE NULL END) AS comments
FROM mimic_hosp.labevents le
where le.ITEMID in
-- blood gases
(
    52028 -- specimen
  , 50801 -- aado2
  , 50802 -- base excess
  , 50803 -- bicarb
  , 50804 -- calc tot co2
  , 50805 -- carboxyhgb
  , 50806 -- chloride
  -- , 52390 -- chloride, WB CL-
  , 50807 -- comments
  , 50808 -- free calcium
  , 50809 -- glucose
  , 50810 -- hct
  , 50811 -- hgb
  , 50813 -- lactate
  , 50814 -- methemoglobin
  , 50815 -- o2 flow
  , 50816 -- fio2
  , 50817 -- o2 sat
  , 50818 -- pco2
  , 50819 -- peep
  , 50820 -- pH
  , 50821 -- pO2
  , 50822 -- potassium
  -- , 52408 -- potassium, WB K+
  , 50823 -- required O2
  , 50824 -- sodium
  -- , 52411 -- sodium, WB NA +
  , 50825 -- temperature
)
GROUP BY le.specimen_id
)
, stg_spo2 as
(
  select subject_id, charttime
    -- avg here is just used to group SpO2 by charttime
    , AVG(valuenum) as SpO2
  FROM mimic_icu.chartevents
  where ITEMID = 220277 -- O2 saturation pulseoxymetry
  and valuenum > 0 and valuenum <= 100
  group by subject_id, charttime
)
, stg_fio2 as
(
  select subject_id, charttime
    -- pre-process the FiO2s to ensure they are between 21-100%
    , max(
        case
          when valuenum > 0.2 and valuenum <= 1
            then valuenum * 100
          -- improperly input data - looks like O2 flow

message.content:
Based on the search results, I can see that itemid 50893 corresponds to "Calcium, Total" which is part of the Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP) in MIMIC-IV. This is a blood chemistry test that measures total calcium levels.

The SQL query you provided is correct for retrieving the lab values and reference ranges for total calcium:

```sql
SELECT itemid, valuenum, ref_range_lower, ref_range_upper
FROM mimiciv_hosp.labevents
WHERE itemid = 50893
```

**Key information about itemid 50893:**
- **Test Name**: Calcium, Total
- **Test Fluid**: Blood
- **Test Category**: Chemistry
- **LOINC Code**: 2000-8
- **Panel**: Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP)

This query will return all total calcium lab measurements from the MIMIC-IV database along with their reference ranges (normal value ranges). The `valuenum` column contains the numeric lab values, while `ref_range_lower` and `ref_range_upper` contain the lower and upper bounds of the normal reference range for this test.

- Light-blue gradient background, bottom-left semi-transparent simplified Youth League emblem.  
- Main title: bold Heiti 36 pt; subtitle: KaiTi 28 pt dark gray; footer: SimSun 14 pt.  

Script  
(smile, 2-second pause)  
Hello everyone, Iâ€™m XXX. Today I want to use this PPT to tell you why Iâ€™m runningâ€”not to be a â€œhigh-up cadre,â€ but to be the teammate who reaches out and gets things done.

Slide 2: About Me  
Copy  
- Basics: XXX | Suzhou, Jiangsu | Major XX Class XX | Communist Youth League member  
- Tags: Ice-breaker Â· Ready helper Â· Closer  
- Track record: As high-school class president, compiled a â€œHobby Handbookâ€ for 32 classmates so we clicked within a week; for two weeks straight I typed up math notes for a sick classmate and checked his progress daily so he didnâ€™t fall behind.  

Image  
- Left third: round cropped smiling photo, light-blue border.  
- Right two-thirds: topâ€”basics & color-box tags; bottomâ€”bullet points starting with âœ….  

Script  
(pointing at photo)  
Quick intro: Iâ€™m from Suzhou. In high school I made that hobby handbookâ€”suddenly guitar people found guitar people, board-game fans found board-game fans, and the room warmed up. For the sick classmate I asked â€œGot this part?â€ every day until he said â€œAll clear,â€ because I finish what I start.

Slide 3: My Edge  
Copy  
- Edge 1: Proactive â€“ Already double-checked contact info for 15 classmates so nothingâ€™s missing.  
- Edge 2: Coordinator â€“ Rescheduled three class events into staggered slots, pushing attendance from 60 % to 90 %.  
- Edge 3: Closer â€“ Todo-list addict; high-school class tasks 100 % done with feedback.  

Image

Script  
(pointing)  
Three reasons Iâ€™ll deliver: First, I proactively verified every phone number. Second, I asked everyoneâ€™s free periods, re-booked events, and 90 % showed. Third, I carry a notebookâ€”task done, tick; task failed, never happened.

Slide 4: What the Job Means  
Copy  
Title: To me, Branch Secretary = 3 Roles  
1. Paperwork clerk â€“ Handle Youth League transfers, â€œYouth Learningâ€ modules, spare you the hassle.  
2. Ice-breaker â€“ Launch activities so we click fast.  
3. Go-to pal â€“ Collect needs, give feedback, make everyone feel owned.  

Image  
Top-centered title; below, three â€œpin-shapeâ€ cards with circle icons (file, people, heart) and wrapped text.  

Script  
(eye contact)  
Itâ€™s not an â€œoffice,â€ itâ€™s three jobs: clerk who kills red tape, ice-breaker who throws the first activity, and pal you can DM any worry.

Slide 5: 30-Day Action Plan  
Copy  
Title: If elected, Iâ€™ll do these 3 things in Month 1  
1. Paperwork Aid â€“ 3-day â€œYouth League Cheat-Sheetâ€ in group chat; 1-hour weekly office hour for one-on-one help.  
2. Hobby Ice-Break â€“ Interest survey this week â†’ online 1-sentence share next week â†’ mini offline meetups after.  
3. Warm Touch â€“ Friday â€œWeekend Tipsâ€ (library hrs, weather); reach out to anyone still quiet and offer a campus walk.  

Image  
Three vertical strips: big â€œ1 2 3,â€ bold title, arrow bullets â‰¤10 chars each; right-side doodles (booklet, form, reminder).  

Script  
(step-by-step)  
Vote me and Month 1 looks like this: Cheat-sheet drops in 3 days, I sit every week for questions; survey goes out Friday, we Zoom-share hobbies Monday; Friday tips hit your phone, and if you feel lost, Iâ€™ll walk you to the library myself.

Slide 6: Promise & Ask  
Copy  
Promise: Be the one who reaches first, does the thoughtful thing, builds a warm league.  
Ask: Please vote for meâ€”your choice will be the right one!  
Footer: Thank you!  

Image  
Light-blue gradient, center semi-transparent emblem.  
Promise: bold Heiti 32 pt centered; ask: red KaiTi 28 pt centered; thank-you: SimSun 24 pt centered.  

Script  
(step forward)  
I canâ€™t promise I know everything, but I promise Iâ€™ll always reach out first. Give me your vote and Iâ€™ll turn every small task into proof you were right. Thank you! (bow)

messages.name: search

messages.content:
Based on currently available public sources, no complete list of county magistrates of Gaoqing County, Shandong, during the Nationalist Government period from 1927 to 1945 has been found.

Special notes:

- Gaoqing County was formally established in 1948 through the merger of Gaoyuan County and Qingcheng County;
- Therefore, between 1927 and 1945, Gaoqing County did not yet exist; its territory was then part of Gaoyuan and Qingcheng counties;
- The only information located so far is a general statement that Gaoyuan and Qingcheng counties came under the Nationalist Tenth Administrative Inspectorate District between 1936 and 1942, but no individual magistratesâ€™ names are given.

In summary, a complete list of county magistrates for Gaoqing County (or its predecessors Gaoyuan and Qingcheng counties) for 1927â€“1945 cannot presently be supplied. Further consultation is recommended of:

- Shandong Provincial Gazetteer: Biographies
- Gaoqing County Gazetteer, or the Gaoyuan and Qingcheng county gazetteers
- Republican-era archives held by the Shandong Provincial Archives or Zibo Municipal Archives

If you have a more specific year or personal name to pursue, I can continue the search.
So, what about the successive county magistrates of Qingcheng?

messages.content:
You are Kimi, an AI assistant developed by Moonshot AI.  
  
When faced with logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.  

Today is: August 13, 2025, Wednesday
The difference between a heatmap and a monitoring dashboard

Heatmaps and dashboards are two common yet fundamentally different tools in data visualization, differing in purpose, context, and interaction. Their core distinctions can be summarized as:

---

### 1. Core Purpose  
- **Heatmap**  
  **Pattern discovery**: Uses color intensity to reveal density, frequency, or strength, helping users instantly spot anomalies, hotspots, or cold zones.  
  *Examples*: website click heatmap (red = high-click areas), traffic flow heatmap (red = congested roads).

- **Dashboard**  
  **Real-time status monitoring**: Aggregates multi-dimensional KPIs, presenting them as charts, numbers, or progress bars that update live for rapid decision-making.  
  *Examples*: server CPU usage, real-time sales, IoT device status panel.

---

### 2. Data & Time Characteristics  
| Dimension        | Heatmap                              | Dashboard                          |
|------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------------|
| **Time**         | Static or quasi-static (e.g., past 24 h aggregate) | Real-time (second/minute refresh) |
| **Granularity**  | High-dimensional spatial data (geo, page coords) | Structured metrics (values, %, trends) |
| **Interaction**  | Light (zoom, hover for details)      | Rich (filter, drill-down, alerts)  |

---

### 3. Visual Design  
- **Heatmap**  
  â€“ Color mapping is central (e.g., red-yellow-green for high-med-low).  
  â€“ Overlaid on maps, screenshots, matrices.  
- **Dashboard**  
  â€“ Mixed widgets (line charts, gauges, tables, alert lights).  
  â€“ Emphasizes tidy layout and info hierarchy (top-left = critical KPI).

---

### 4. Typical Use Cases  
- **Heatmap**  
  â€“ UX optimization: analyze clicks, dwell time.  
  â€“ Scientific viz: gene expression, urban density.  
- **Dashboard**  
  â€“ Ops monitoring: server health, network latency.  
  â€“ Business monitoring: live sales, inventory alerts.

---

### One-liner  
A **heatmap** is the color-speaking detective; a **dashboard** is the metric-watching steward.
What does a heat map look like?

title: CPU Hierarchy 2024 [PC Processors Tier List] 
url: https://cpuninja.com/cpu-hierarchy/ 
æ•°æ®æ¥æº: CPU Ninja 
date:2025-09-26 
ç‰‡æ®µ1:
When upgrading a computer to get more FPS in games or to be more productive, the GPU and CPU are the primary pieces of hardware that must be changed. The GPUâ€™s role is to handle all visual-related tasks, such as video games, videos, etc., while the CPU handles almost everything else.

With so many processors available on the market and various price ranges, finding the suitable one is never uncomplicated.

To ensure that anybody reading this article makes an informed decision, we have created this **hierarchy of CPUs** from the recent few generations to help you determine what you require.

We are ranking the CPUs in tiers based on their performance in gaming and productivity.

Without further delay, here is the final CPU hierarchy list!

Note: Intelâ€™s 12th-gen CPUs have P (performance), E (effective), and T (threads) indicators under Cores/Threads

Table of ContentsShow

1.  S Tier

2.  A Tier

3.  B Tier

4.  C Tier

5.  D Tier

6.  Final Words On The CPU Hierarchy

The **premium** is where the most potent and costly processors belong. These CPUs are for users wanting to **enhance their FPS** in the most visually challenging games or to do **complex work**.

To achieve top-notch productivity, consider the third-gen Threadripper. It provides exceptional price-to-performance value. One model, the Threadripper 3990X, boasts 64 cores and costs $4000.

Alternatively, the **Threadripper 3960X** is priced at **$1,400** with 24 cores and 48 threads. If you are searching for an Intel solution, the i9-10980XE has 18 cores/ 36 threads at $1000. We wouldnâ€™t suggest these for gaming, though.

To obtain exceptional quality and favorable bargains, consider Intelâ€™s high-grade processors like the i9-13900K, i7-13700K, and i5-13600K. They are priced at $589, $409, and $319, respectively. The 12th gen SKUs are also a wise option.

AMD also offers outstanding gaming performance for a fair value with the Ryzen 7 5800X3D, Ryzen 7 7700X, and Ryzen 5 7600X.

However, AMDâ€™s Ryzen non-X CPUs like the **Ryzen 9 7900**, **Ryzen 7 7700**, and **Ryzen 5 7600** have an even more outstanding price-to-performance ratio.

The recently released **Ryzen 9 7950X3D** and **Ryzen 7 7800X3D** are the fastest gaming CPUs in the world, followed closely by the **Ryzen 9 7900X3D**.

The rest of the Ryzen 7000 series, like the **Ryzen 9 7900X** and **Ryzen 9 7950X**, are also reliable options, especially if youâ€™re leaning toward creative work.

AMDâ€™s **Ryzen 5950X**, **5900X,** and **5700X** are also quite fast CPUs, so they deserve this S-tier classification. The MSRPs are $799, $549, and $299 respectively.

### Gaming

|19.|_IntelCore i7-12700K_|5.0 GHz|8P/4E/20T|125W|

**P â€“ Performance cores, E â€“ Efficiency cores, T â€“ Threads**## A Tier

The A-tier of CPUs consists of recent and older generation CPUs that do not cost an arm and a leg and have a diminished core count.

Here, we have the **Ryzen 5 5600X** and the **Ryzen 5 5600** competing against Intelâ€™s **i5-11600K**. Both of these CPUs are similarly priced and have 6 cores/12 threads. They are also considerably cheaper than S-tier CPUs at around $300.

However, the Ryzen 5 5600 is a significantly superior affordable choice as it only costs **$200**.

The Ryzen **5700G** and **5600G** (AMDâ€™s processors with built-in graphics) can also be positioned here, just under the **i9-10900**.

We also have the processors from two generations ago, the **10700K** and **10900K**.

AMDâ€™s third generation also deserves a place in the top tier. Particularly the Ryzen 3900X and 3700X variants.

Intelâ€™s i3-12100F might appear as simply another i3 with 8 threads only, but it actually performs quite exceptionally, exchanging blows with the 11400F, 3700X, and extra CPUs.## A Tier

We also have the processors from two generations ago, the **10700K** and **10900K**.

AMDâ€™s third generation also deserves a place in the top tier. Particularly the Ryzen 3900X and 3700X variants.

Intelâ€™s i3-12100F might appear as simply another i3 with 8 threads only, but it actually performs quite exceptionally, exchanging blows with the 11400F, 3700X, and extra CPUs.

||Model|Boost Clock|Cores/Threads|TDP|
|-|-|-|-|-|
|1.|_IntelCore i9-11900K_|5.3 GHz|10/16|125W|
|2.|_AMD Ryzen 9 5900X_|4.8 GHz|12/24|105W|
|3.|_Intel Core i5-12600_ K|4.9 GHz|6P/4E/16T|125W|

|11.|_AMD Ryzen 5 5600_|4.4 GHz|6/12|65W|

|20.|_AMD Ryzen 7 3800X/XT_|4.5 GHz/4.7 GHz|8/16|105W|
|21.|_IntelCore i5-10400F_|4.3 GHz|6/12|65W|
|22.|_AMD Ryzen 7 3700X_|4.4 GHz|8/16|65W|## B Tier

We have reached the second-tier of CPUs. Donâ€™t be mistaken; the processors in this category are still more than capable of handling modern games and outputting competitive FPS. Second-tier processors might provide the ideal price-per-performance of all these options.

The Ryzen 3600 was and possibly still is one of AMDâ€™s most cherished processors. A processor with 12 threads and reasonable power consumption sold for just $200. How can someone not adore it?

These days, you could probably obtain the 3600 or even the **3600X** for as little as $180.

Ryzen 3600, one of AMDâ€™s most valued CPUs.

Some of Intelâ€™s 9th-generation CPUs also fit here flawlessly. The **9900K** and even the 8-thread **9700K** are still sufficient enough. Of course, this is at a much cheaper price than MSRP.

||Model|Boost Clock|Cores/Threads|TDP|
|-|-|-|-|-|
|1.|_IntelCore i9-9900K_|5.0 GHz|8/16|95W|
|2.|_IntelCore i7-9700K_|4.9 GHz|8/8|95W|
|3.|_Intel Core i9-9900_|5.0 GHz|8/16|65W|
|4.|_Intel Core i7-9700_|4.7 GHz|8/8|65W|
|5.|_AMD Ryzen 5 5500_|4.2 GHz|6/12|65W|
|6.|_AMD Ryzen 5 3600X_|4.4 GHz|6/12|65W|
|7.|_AMD Ryzen 5 3600_|4.2 GHz|6/12|65W|
|8.|_AMD Ryzen 3 3300X_|4.3 GHz|4/8|95W|
|9.|_IntelCore i5-9600K_|4.6 GHz|6/6|95W|## C Tier

We have entered the group of processors that are starting to reveal their age, shortage of cores, and power, especially when it comes to the latest video games.

AMDâ€™s second generation of Ryzen still provides exceptional value, but its IPC is rather mediocre, leaving a lot to be desired. The same goes for Intelâ€™s 9th generation i5s and i3s.

The Ryzen **2700X** is a reasonably solid option as you can grab it for less than $200 and get an 8-core and 16-thread CPU. However, this is Zen+, donâ€™t mistake it for AMDâ€™s Zen 2 (3600, 3700X, etc.). It is significantly slower in single-core performance.

Intelâ€™s i5s (such as the **9400F)** are also obsolete, considering they are locked to just 6 threads while i3s are stuck at 4 threads. Thatâ€™s **too inadequate** by todayâ€™s standards.

||Model|Boost Clock|Cores/Threads|TDP|
|-|-|-|-|-|
|1.|_IntelCore i3-10300_|4.4 GHz|4/8|65W|
|2.|_IntelCore i5-9400/F_|4.1 GHz|6/6|65W|
|3.|_IntelCore i3-10100_|4.3 GHz|4/8|65W|
|4.|_AMD Ryzen 7 2700X_|4.3 GHz|8/16|105W|
|5.|_AMD Ryzen Pro 4750G_|4.4 GHz|8/16|65W|
|6.|_AMD Ryzen 3 3100_|3.9 GHz|4/8|65W|
|7.|_AMD Ryzen 3400G_|4.2 GHz|4/8|65W|## D Tier

This is the D-level, a group of CPUs that can significantly impede your GPU from reaching its maximum capability, especially if you possess a high-end GPU like an RTX 3090 or RX 6900XT.

Even considering the modest costs of CPUs such as the **2600X**, **i3-9100,** and others, they are challenging to recommend as there are similarly priced SKUs with substantially better performance.

||Model|Boost Clock|Cores/Threads|TDP|
|-|-|-|-|-|
|_1._|_AMD Ryzen 7 2700_|4.1 GHz|8/16|65W|
|_2._|_AMD Ryzen 5 2600X_|4.2 GHz|6/12|95W|
|_3._|_AMD Ryzen 5 2600_|3.9 GHz|6/12|65W|
|_4._|_Intel Core i3-9100_|4.2 GHz|4/4|65W|
|_5._|_AMD Ryzen 3 3200G_|4.0 GHz|4/4|65W|
|_6._|_AMD Ryzen 5 2400G_|3.9 GHz|4/8|65W|
|_7._|_AMD Ryzen 3 2200G_|3.7 GHz|4/4|65W|
|_8._|_Intel Pentium G6605_|4.3 GHz|2/4|58W|

## Final Words On The CPU Hierarchy

This tiered list contains approximately 40 CPUs. That is a relatively small number considering there are hundreds of CPUs out there. However, we decided to limit our list to the final three generations of processors from both AMD and Intel.

There are also some exclusions from the latest generations as some CPUs can only be bought as part of an OEM PC or pre-built systems.

These CPU rankings are based on numerous review websites and YouTube tech channels, including Tomâ€™s Hardware, Hardware Unboxed, and Gamers Nexus. We also compared results from benchmarks such as Cinebench and Geekbench 5.

# Rust Programming Lesson 1: Your First Steps into Programming
*A comprehensive guide for absolute beginners with no prior programming experience*

## What You Will Learn Today
- What is a computer program?
- What is the Rust programming language?
- How to set up your computer for programming
- Writing your very first program
- Understanding every single word and symbol you write

---

## Part 1: Understanding the Basics

### What is a Computer Program?

Let's start with something simple. Imagine you're giving instructions to a very obedient but extremely literal-minded robot friend.

If you say: "Please bring me a glass of water," the robot might:
1. Stand still (because you didn't say to walk)
2. Or bring you the glass without water (because you didn't mention filling it)
3. Or bring you an empty glass from the bathroom instead of the kitchen

Computers are exactly like this robot - they follow instructions PRECISELY. A **program** is simply a list of these extremely specific instructions written in a language the computer understands.

### What is Rust?

**Rust** is one of these languages we use to write instructions for computers. Think of it like learning French or Spanish, but instead of talking to people, you're talking to computers.

Rust is special because:
- It helps prevent many common mistakes
- It runs very fast
- It's used to build important software like web browsers, operating systems, and game engines

---

## Part 2: Setting Up Your Computer

Before we start programming, we need to prepare your computer. This is like setting up a kitchen before you can cook.

### Step 1: Installing Rust

**Windows:**
1. Open your web browser
2. Go to: https://rustup.rs/
3. Click the big button that says "rustup-init.exe"
4. When it downloads, double-click to run it
5. Press **1** when it asks for installation options
6. Wait for it to finish (this might take 5-10 minutes)

**Mac:**
1. Open "Terminal" (you can find it by pressing Cmd+Space and typing "terminal")
2. Copy and paste this command:
   ```bash
   curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
   ```
3. Press Enter and follow the instructions

**Linux:**
1. Open your terminal
2. Use the same command as Mac:
   ```bash
   curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
   ```

### Step 2: Testing Your Installation

After installation, close your terminal/command prompt and reopen it. Then type:

```bash
rustc --version
```

You should see something like:
```
rustc 1.75.0 (82e1608df 2023-12-21)
```

Don't worry if the numbers are different - this just means it worked!

---

## Part 3: Your First Program Explained

Let's write the simplest possible program. This tradition is called "Hello, World!" - it's like learning to say "Hello" in a new language.

### Creating Your Program

1. Create a new folder on your desktop called "rust-learning"
2. Open your terminal/command prompt
3. Navigate to this folder:
   - Windows: `cd Desktop\rust-learning`
   - Mac/Linux: `cd Desktop/rust-learning`
4. Create a new project:
   ```bash
   cargo new hello_world
   ```
5. Go into the new folder:
   ```bash
   cd hello_world
   ```

### Understanding Your First Code

Open the file `hello_world/src/main.rs` in any text editor (like Notepad). You'll see:

```rust
fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}
```

Let's understand EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER:

#### Line 1: `fn main() {`

- **`fn`**: This is short for "function". Think of a function like a recipe - it's a set of instructions with a name.
- **`main`**: This is the name of our function. The computer always starts with the `main` function - it's like the first page of instructions.
- **`()`**: These parentheses are where we would put ingredients (called "parameters") if our recipe needed any. Empty means no ingredients needed.
- **`{`**: This curly bracket means "start of instructions". Everything between `{` and `}` belongs to this function.

#### Line 2: `    println!("Hello, world!");`

- **`println!`**: This is a command that means "print line". The `!` is special - it tells us this is a "macro" (a special kind of command).
- **`(`**: Opening parenthesis for the command
- **`"Hello, world!"`**: This is called a "string" - think of it as text wrapped in quotes
- **`)`**: Closing parenthesis for the command
- **`;`**: This semicolon means "end of this instruction". It's like a period at the end of a sentence.

#### Line 3: `}`

- **`}`**: This closes our function - it means "end of instructions for main"

### Running Your Program

In your terminal, type:
```bash
cargo run
```

You should see:
```
   Compiling hello_world v0.1.0
    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.52s
     Running `target/debug/hello_world`
Hello, world!
```

Congratulations! You just wrote and ran your first computer program!

---

## Part 4: Understanding Every Detail

### What is Cargo?

Cargo is like a helpful assistant for Rust programming. It:
- Builds (compiles) your programs
- Downloads helpful tools (called "crates")
- Manages your project files

### What is "Compiling"?

Computers don't understand Rust directly. Compiling is like translation - it converts your Rust code into instructions the computer can understand.

Think of it like this:
- You write in English (Rust code)
- The compiler translates to Machine Language (0s and 1s)
- The computer runs the translated version

### Understanding Files and Folders

Your `hello_world` folder looks like this:

```
hello_world/
â”œâ”€â”€ Cargo.toml          # Project configuration (like a recipe book cover)
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ main.rs         # Your actual code (the recipe)
â””â”€â”€ target/             # Where compiled programs go
```

**Cargo.toml** contains information about your project:
```toml
[package]
name = "hello_world"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"

[dependencies]
```

Each part means:
- **`[package]`**: This section describes your project
- **`name`**: What you call your project
- **`version`**: What version this is (starts at 0.1.0)
- **`edition`**: Which version of Rust rules to use
- **`[dependencies]`**: Where you list any helper tools you want to use

---

## Part 5: Making Changes

Let's modify your program to understand it better.

### Experiment 1: Changing the Message

Change `main.rs` to:

```rust
fn main() {
    println!("Hello, my name is [Your Name]!");
    println!("I'm learning Rust programming!");
}
```

Run it with `cargo run` again.

### Experiment 2: Multiple Lines

Add more lines:

```rust
fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
    println!("This is my second line");
    println!("Rust is fun!");
}
```

### Understanding the Output

Notice that each `println!` creates a new line. This is why it's called "print LINE" - it automatically adds a line break after each message.

---

## Part 6: Common Questions and Troubleshooting

### "I got an error!"

Don't worry - errors are normal! Let's decode common ones:

**Error: "expected one of ., ;"**
- This means you forgot a semicolon `;` at the end of a line

**Error: "unresolved import"**
- This means you tried to use something that doesn't exist

**Error: "no such file or directory"**
- Make sure you're in the right folder when running `cargo run`

### "Nothing happens when I run cargo run"
- Make sure you saved your file after making changes
- Check that you're in the correct folder (the one with Cargo.toml)

### "I don't understand something"
- That's completely normal! Programming takes time to learn
- Try reading the explanation out loud
- Take breaks and come back to it

---

## Part 7: Practice Exercises

Try these to reinforce your learning:

### Exercise 1: Personal Introduction
Create a program that prints:
```
Hello! My name is [your name].
I'm learning Rust programming.
Today is [day of week].
```

### Exercise 2: ASCII Art
Create a program that prints a simple picture:
```
    /\_/\
   ( o.o )
    > ^ <
```

### Exercise 3: Multiple Messages
Create a program that prints:
```
Starting program...
Loading...
Welcome to Rust!
```

---

## Part 8: What's Next?

In the next lesson, we will learn about:
- **Variables**: How to store and use information
- **Numbers**: Doing math with the computer
- **User Input**: Making programs that respond to what users type
- **Making Decisions**: Programs that can think (if statements)

---

## Summary Checklist

By now you should understand:
- [ ] What a computer program is
- [ ] What the Rust programming language is
- [ ] How to install Rust on your computer
- [ ] How to create a new project with `cargo new`
- [ ] Every character in your first "Hello, world!" program
- [ ] How to run your program with `cargo run`
- [ ] What Cargo.toml is for
- [ ] How to make simple changes to your program

Remember: Programming is like learning a new language. It feels strange at first, but with practice, it becomes natural. Don't worry if you don't understand everything immediately - that's completely normal!

---

## Glossary of Terms

- **Program**: A list of instructions for a computer
- **Rust**: A programming language
- **Function**: A named set of instructions (like a recipe)
- **main**: The special function where programs start
- **String**: Text wrapped in quotes
- **Compile**: Translate human code into computer code
- **Cargo**: Rust's helper tool for building projects
- **Project**: A folder containing your program files
- **Run**: Execute your program
- **Terminal**: A text-based way to control your computer

---

*Congratulations on completing your first Rust lesson! Take time to experiment with what you've learned before moving on to Lesson 2.*

message.content:
Below is a â€œmobile-firstâ€ survival guide: everything you need to do the very same Lesson 1, but on a phone or tablet, with no PC, no root, and almost no typing.  
(The steps are ordered from â€œzero-installâ€ to â€œpower-userâ€; stop at the level that feels comfortable.)

--------------------------------------------------
1. Zero-install path (browser only, 2 min)
--------------------------------------------------
1. Open https://play.rust-lang.org in Chrome/Firefox/Safari.  
   â€“ This is the official Rust playground; it compiles and runs code in the cloud.  
2. Erase the default code, paste the lesson:

```rust
fn main() {
    println!("Hello from my phone!");
}
```

3. Press the big blue â€œRunâ€ button.  
   â€“ You just â€œcargo runâ€ without installing anything.  
4. Experiment inside the same tab: change the text, press Run again.  
   â€“ Every successful run is the same mental win as on a desktop.

Tip: add the playground to your home screen (â‹® â†’ â€œAdd to Home screenâ€) so it opens like an app.

--------------------------------------------------
2. Tiny-keyboard path (clipboard snippets)
--------------------------------------------------
Typing braces on a phone is painful, so keep a â€œsnippet noteâ€:

Create a new note (Google Keep, Apple Notes, whatever) titled â€œRust snippetsâ€ and save these two lines exactly:

```
fn main() {
    println!("");
}
```

Whenever you need a fresh program:  
- copy the snippet,  
- paste into the playground,  
- edit only the text inside the quotes.

--------------------------------------------------
3. Offline path (Android only, 10 min setup)
--------------------------------------------------
If you often have no data/Wi-Fi:

1. Install â€œTermuxâ€ from F-Droid (open-source) or the Play Store.  
2. Inside Termux run these three commands (copy-paste one by one):

```bash
pkg update && pkg upgrade -y
pkg install rust -y
mkdir ~/rust && cd ~/rust
```

3. Create the file with the built-in nano editor:

```bash
nano main.rs
```

- Inside nano: paste the Hello-World code.  
- Ctrl-O (Volume-Down + O on most phones) â†’ Enter â†’ Ctrl-X.

4. Compile & run:

```bash
rustc main.rs && ./main
```

You will see:

```
Hello from my phone!
```

You now have the same toolchain as on a PC (rustc, cargo, etc.) inside your pocket.

--------------------------------------------------
4. iOS offline path (iPhone/iPad, 5 min)
--------------------------------------------------
Apple does not allow compilers in the App Store, but â€œiSH Shellâ€ (free, Alpine Linux) works:

1. Install â€œiSHâ€ from the App Store.  
2. In iSH type:

```sh
apk add rust cargo
```

3. Follow the same nano/main.rs steps as for Android above.

--------------------------------------------------
5. Learning workflow that respects small screens
--------------------------------------------------
A. One-concept-per-file  
   â€“ Keep every experiment in its own file (ex1.rs, ex2.rs â€¦) so you can reopen it in nano without scrolling.

B. Use â€œcargo scriptâ€ for micro-projects  
   â€“ Install once: `cargo install cargo-script`  
   â€“ Then a whole program can live in a single file:

```rust
#!/usr/bin/env cargo-script
fn main() {
    println!("Quick test");
}
```

Run with:  
```
cargo script ex1.rs
```

No folder structure needed.

C. Vertical split in Termux  
   â€“ Swipe from the left â†’ â€œNEW SESSIONâ€ â†’ you now have two panes:  
     top = nano editor, bottom = compiler output.  
   â€“ This mimics an IDE even on a 6-inch screen.

--------------------------------------------------
6. Thumb-typing tricks
--------------------------------------------------
- Long-press the single quote to get double quotes.  
- Gboard / SwiftKey: add â€œrustâ€ to the personal dictionary so fn, println, main are autocompleted.  
- Use a bluetooth foldable keyboard ($15) when you practise for more than 15 minâ€”your speed jumps 5Ã— instantly.

--------------------------------------------------
7. Mini exercises you can finish in one metro ride
--------------------------------------------------
1. Change the message to your name.  
2. Print three lines:  
   ```
   Hello
   Rust
   Mobile
   ```
3. Print a tiny cat:
   ```
   /\_/\
  ( o.o )
   > ^ <
   ```
4. Print the result of 5 + 3 (hint: `println!("{}", 5 + 3);`).

Each exercise is small enough to do while waiting for coffee, yet you still practise the exact skills from Lesson 1.

--------------------------------------------------
8. When you finally reach a computer
--------------------------------------------------
Everything you wrote on the playground or in Termux is valid Rustâ€”just copy the file contents into a new `cargo new myproject` and continue with Lesson 2. Zero re-typing.

--------------------------------------------------
Key takeaway  
--------------------------------------------------
Mobile is not a handicap; it is a constrained environment that forces you to focus on the language itself instead of fancy tools. If you can compile and run ten tiny programs on your phone, you will already think in Rust by the time you sit at a keyboard.

AI cannot predict winning lottery numbers. Lotteries are designed to be random, and no algorithmâ€”AI includedâ€”can foresee or influence genuinely random events.

AI cannot predict winning lottery numbers; here is the analysis:

### The essential nature of lottery numbers  
Lottery numbers are drawn at random under rigorously designed rules of randomness. In ball-drawing games, for example, numbered balls are tumbled by a machine; computer-based lotteries rely on complex algorithms and random-number generators. Like coin flips, each draw is independent and random, unaffected by any past results, so no predictable pattern can emerge.

### How AI works  
AI learns from large data sets and identifies patterns and correlations. This works only when the data contain exploitable regularities. Random lottery data have no such regularities; no matter how many historical draws an AI ingests, it cannot learn anything that will foretell the next winning combination.

### The harm of believing AI can predict numbers  
Claims that AI can forecast winning numbers foster gambling fantasies, lure people into overspending on tickets, disrupt personal finances, and can trigger family conflict or fraudâ€”undermining the charitable purpose of lotteries.

### Where AI is genuinely useful  
Although AI cannot predict numbers, it can assist lottery operations: analyzing sales data to optimize retailer locations, detecting anomalous transactions to curb illegal sales, and helping maintain industry integrity.

In short, recognize AIâ€™s limits, ignore false promises, treat lotteries rationally, and use AI only for what it can actually do.

Yesâ€”price is almost always negotiable, provided you choose the right moment and frame the request professionally. A few practical pointers:

1. **Wait for the natural opening**  
   - If youâ€™re a buyer: after the seller has asked â€œAre you happy with the quote?â€ or when youâ€™re ready to place a larger/multiple order.  
   - If youâ€™re a seller: after the buyer has shown serious interest (second meeting, request for formal proposal, etc.).

2. **Give a reason that benefits both sides**  
   â€œIf we could adjust the unit price to $X, I could increase the order to 500 pcs and place a 30 % deposit this weekâ€”would that work for you?â€

3. **Use conditional language**  
   â€œWould you be open to revisiting the price if we â€¦?â€ keeps the tone collaborative instead of confrontational.

4. **Leave an escape hatch**  
   Signal that youâ€™re still keen even if the price canâ€™t move: â€œIf the figure is already your best, I understand and we can proceed as-is.â€

5. **Put it in writing once agreed**  
   Summarize any new price in an email or revised PO so both sides have a record.

In short, politely askâ€”donâ€™t demandâ€”at the point when the other party has something to gain (volume, speed, certainty), and youâ€™ll rarely offend anyone.

# Pseudo Internship Challenge

## Overview

This is a coding challenge repository containing:
- **src/**: Core implementation files
  - `email_processor.py`: Email processing functionality
  - `gmail_client.py`: Gmail client mock implementation
  - `__init__.py`: Package initialization
- **tests/**: Test suite
  - `test_email_processor.py`: Email processor tests
  - `test_data_generator.py`: Test data generation utilities
  - `__init__.py`: Test package initialization

## Submission Instructions

1. **Fork this repository** to your GitHub account
2. **Clone your fork** locally
3. **Implement the required changes** in your fork
4. **Test your implementation** to ensure all tests pass
5. **Create a Pull Request** from your fork to the `batch-0` branch of this repository

### Pull Request Requirements
- Target branch: `batch-0`
- Include a clear description of your changes
- Ensure all tests pass before submitting
- Follow existing code style and conventions

## Getting Started

```bash
# Clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/pseudo-internship-challenge.git
cd pseudo-internship-challenge

# Install dependencies (if any)
pip install -r requirements.txt  # if requirements.txt exists

# Run tests
python -m pytest tests/ -v
```

# Run all tests

# Run tests in a specific directory
pytest tests/

# Run tests matching a specific pattern

Permalink: Test Structure

### Writing Tests

Permalink: Writing Tests

Each test file should follow these conventions:

1.  Use descriptive test names with `test_` prefix

2.  Group related tests in classes with `Test` prefix

3.  Use fixtures for common setup

4.  Mock external API calls

5.  Include both positive and negative test cases

Example:

```
def test_email_processing_warm_intro():
    processor = EmailProcessor()
    email_content = "I wanted to introduce you to..."
    result = processor._is_warm_intro(email_content)
    assert result == True
```

Permalink: Security Notes

2.  Never commit sensitive credentials to version control

3.  Use appropriate access controls for the API endpoints

4.  Regularly rotate API keys and credentials

5.  Monitor API usage and implement rate limiting

## Send emails using SMTP

### Asynchronous email sending

For asynchronous email sending you need to use Pythonâ€™s **asyncio** library along with **aiosmtplib**, an asynchronous SMTP client.

This modification allows your script to send emails without blocking the execution of your program, making it more efficient, especially when sending multiple emails or performing other tasks concurrently.

For simplicity, Iâ€™ll be sending a text/plain email to a single recipient without attachments and embedded images. Hereâ€™s how it works.

First, make sure to install the **aiosmtplib**.

Now, hereâ€™s the script:

**Quick breakdown**:

-  **Asynchronous function definition**: The script now defines asynchronous functions using `async def`.

-  **Async functionality**: Utilizing â€˜asyncio and â€˜aiosmtplibâ€™, the script establishes an SMTP connection asynchronously, logs in, and sends the email. This approach allows for non-blocking email sending, which is particularly useful in applications that require maintaining responsiveness while performing network operations.

-  **Running the script**: The `main` async function sets up the email details and calls send\_email\_async to send the email. It demonstrates how to run asynchronous tasks in Python effectively, with `asyncio.run(main())` bootstrapping the asynchronous execution.

Email is a critical means of communication in todayâ€™s world, but it can be time-consuming and tedious to send out emails manually. Fortunately, Python provides a simple and efficient way to automate email sending and receiving tasks. In this article, we will explore how to use Python to automate emails, starting with the basics and moving on to more advanced techniques.

## Getting started with Pythonâ€™s built-in `smtplib` library

The simplest way to automate email sending in Python is by using the built-in `smtplib` library. The `smtplib` library is a powerful tool that allows you to send emails using the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP). To use the `smtplib` library, you must first set up an email account that can be used to send emails programmatically.

## Sending email with Python

Once you have set up your email account, you can use Python to send emails. To send an email, you will need to import the `smtplib` library, create an instance of the `SMTP` class, log in to your email account, and send the email.

Hereâ€™s an example code snippet that sends a simple email using Python:

```
import smtplibsmtp_server = 'smtp.gmail.com'
smtp_port = 587
smtp_username = '[EMAIL]'
smtp_password = 'yourpassword'from_email = '[EMAIL]'
to_email = '[EMAIL]'
subject = 'Hello, world!'
body = 'This is a test email.'message = f'Subject: {subject}\n\n{body}'with smtplib.SMTP(smtp_server, smtp_port) as smtp:
    smtp.starttls()
    smtp.login(smtp_username, smtp_password)
    smtp.sendmail(from_email, to_email, message)
```

-  This code sends an email from `[EMAIL]` to `[EMAIL]` with the subject "Hello, world!" and the body "This is a test email."

-  The `starttls()` method enables Transport Layer Security (TLS) encryption, which ensures that the email is transmitted securely.

-  The `login()` method logs in to your email account using your username and password.

-  Finally, the `sendmail()` method sends the email to the recipient.

## Establishing a culture of continuous testing and learning

CMOs should experiment with different elements of email campaigns to determine what works best. Marketers can test subject lines, email designs, or send times, analyze the results, and use the insights gained to improve future emails for better performance.

The challenge here lies in executing rigorous testing protocols to validate the effectiveness of segmentation strategies. This means setting up A/B tests to determine the success of different email subject lines for different segments, for instance. The CMO must ensure that these tests yield meaningful data to inform future campaigns without exceeding budget constraints and while maintaining the brandâ€™s integrity in a competitive environment thatâ€™s constantly in flux.

Finally, establishing a culture of continuous testing and optimization is crucial. By implementing A/B testing protocols, marketers can assess the impact of different email subject lines on open rates and conversions. These tests should be designed to produce statistically significant results that can inform future campaigns. For example, if a test reveals that personalized subject lines significantly outperform generic ones, this insight can be used to tailor future emails. Training teams to understand and act on these insights keeps testing as a core part of the marketing strategy and not a rigid box-ticking exercise.

## How to send emails with Python

### Sending emails in Python with an email API

Using a third-party email API is a great option if you want to create more advanced workflows with additional email-sending features and tracking options. MailerSend also provides an official Python SDK, making the implementation straightforward and efficient.

**If youâ€™d like to try this out MailerSendâ€™s email API**, you can sign up for free and use a trial domain for testing purposes. It only takes a few minutes to sign up and you can start sending immediately.

**To use the API:**

1\. Create an account for free and sign in.

2\. From the dashboard, click **Domains** in the left-hand menu. If youâ€™d like to use your own domain, you can add one by clicking **Add domain**, or you can use the trial domain.

3\. Next to the domain you want to use, click **Manage**. In the API section, click **Generate new token**. A pop-up will appear, enter a recognizable name for your new API token, set the permissions, and then click **Create token**.

4\. Your API key will be generated and displayed. Make sure you copy and save it somewhere, or download it, as you wonâ€™t be able to access this again for security purposes.

Check out our API docs.

To get started, install MailerSendâ€™s Python SDK in your Python app:

```
$ python -m pip install mailersend
```

**Note:**

Python 3.6.1 or higher is required.

Youâ€™ll also need to install the _requests_ library to make HTTP requests to the MailerSend API:

```
pip install requests
```

Next, we recommend using environment variables for your API key and other sensitive information to avoid exposing it in your code.

You can do this in your Terminal:

```
export MAILERSEND_API_KEY="your_api_key"
```

Or by creating a .env file with the following in your project directory:

```
MAILERSEND_API_KEY=your_api_key
```

This is the cover designed for a Cantonese opera album, depicting a traditional Cantonese opera scene. The central figure is a female performer dressed in a vibrant red-and-gold costume and an elaborate headdress, her facial makeup vivid and expressive. Behind her stands a classic Chinese opera stage; red curtains and ornate decorations create a rich atmosphere. Lighting emphasizes the actressâ€™s dynamic pose, perfectly showcasing the allure of Cantonese opera. The album title, rendered in elegant Chinese calligraphy across the top, features a subtle glow that makes it stand out.

Lunch: Fried rice with diced lean pork, green peas & corn, side of blanched spinach, winter-melon shrimp soup  
Afternoon snack: Orange, unsalted nuts (small pack)  

**Thursday**  
Breakfast: Buckwheat pancakes, unsweetened yogurt, peach slices  
Lunch: Whole-wheat noodles with beef & tomato sauce, side of coleslaw, black fungus chicken soup  
Afternoon snack: Pear, low-sugar cheese cube  

**Friday**  
Breakfast: Purple-sweet-potato porridge, vegetable bun, tea egg  
Lunch: Red rice, steamed tofu with minced chicken, stir-fried kale & garlic, radish rib soup  
Afternoon snack: Kiwi, roasted seaweed  

**Key points**  
1. Staples alternate whole grains & refined grains 1:2 to boost fiber while maintaining energy.  
2. Daily 300â€“400 g vegetables, 150â€“200 g fruit; dark-colored veggies â‰¥ 50 %.  
3. Protein: 1 egg, 300 ml milk, 50â€“100 g lean meat/fish/shrimp, plus beans 2Ã— week.  
4. Cooking: steamed, boiled, braised; oil â‰¤ 25 g/day, salt â‰¤ 3 g/day, no added sugar.  
5. Replace nuts with pumpkin seeds if allergies; swap fruits by season.

messages.content:
Based on the search results, Iâ€™ve compiled a balanced, kid-friendly lunch menu for elementary students that covers an entire week. It supplies age-appropriate amounts of protein, vitamins, dietary fiber and carbohydrates for 6- to 12-year-olds.

---

### ğŸ—“ One-Week Nutritious Lunch Plan for Elementary Students (Monâ€“Fri)

| Day | Staple | Meat Dish | Veg Dishes | Soup | Fruit / Dairy |
|-----|--------|-----------|------------|------|---------------|
| Mon | White rice | Salt-pepper spare-riblets | Chicken-breast with wild rice stems, baby bok choy | Shredded veggie soup | Yogurt |
| Tue | White rice | Braised rooster | Pork-onion-pepper, tofu napa cabbage | Tomato-egg soup | Banana |
| Wed | White rice | Beef-potato stew | Minced-pork eggplant, celery-dried tofu | Pork-corn rib soup | Plain milk |
| Thu | White rice | Five-spice drumstick | Pork-cabbage-vermicelli, garlic yard-long beans | Loofah-egg soup | Apple |
| Fri | White rice | Scallion sautÃ©ed prawns | Pork â€œvegetarian chickenâ€, stir-fried lotus root | Mushroom-tofu soup | Sweet pear |

---

### âœ… Nutrition Tips
- **Staple**: White rice base; occasionally mix in brown rice, millet or red beans for extra fiber.  
- **Protein**: Include 1â€“2 quality sources dailyâ€”poultry, beef, fish, shrimp, or soy products.  
- **Vegetables**: Offer at least two kinds per meal, pairing dark greens with root veggies for vitamins and fiber.  
- **Soup**: Keep it light and low-salt; favor tomato, seaweed, corn, tofu, etc.  
- **Fruit / Dairy**: Serve fruit or yogurt after the meal for vitamin C and calcium to aid absorption.

Need seasonal, regional or special-diet (allergy, vegetarian) tweaks? Let me know.

messages.content:
You are Kimi, an AI assistant developed by Moonshot AI.  
  
When faced with logic questions like comparisons or counting, think step by step before answering.  

Today is: August 13, 2025, Wednesday
I want to build a stablecoin-based business; what should the technical target architecture look like?

Build a business that receives stablecoins: a comprehensive technical-target architecture

1. Payment & Settlement  
- Multi-chain in-bound interface (ETH, TRON, BSC, etc.) for USDT/USDC/BUSD  
- REST/WS APIs for receive & query  
- Real-time tx monitoring & confirmation  
- Wallet-mgmt layer: multi-coin, HD, address-whitelisting, auto-labeling  
- Flow-tracking ledger: in, out, internal transfers, full audit trail  
- Auto-settlement engine: rule-based splitting, swapping, forwarding  

2. Security & Risk  
- AES-256/RSA-4096 encryption at rest & in transit  
- HSM + MPC + cold-storage for private keys; no single-point cleartext  
- ML risk-score per tx: velocity, mixer exposure, sanctions lists  
- 24Ã—7 anomaly detection & auto-freeze  
- Continuous compliance scan (OFAC, FATF travel rule, local AML)  

3. User & Customer Mgmt  
- KYC: ID doc OCR + liveness + gov data match; stepped KYC for limits  
- MFA: TOTP, FIDO2, biometrics  
- CRM: 360Â° profile, tx history, ticket system, omni-channel support  

4. Infrastructure  
- Self-hosted full nodes + load-balanced backups; quorum-based failover  
- HA k8s clusters across 3 AZs; auto-scaling, blue-green deploys  
- Distributed object storage (S3-compatible) with erasure coding  
- 10 Gbps redundant links; TLS 1.3, mTLS between micro-services  

5. Data & Analytics  
- PostgreSQL for relational data; MongoDB for logs; Kafka for streaming  
- Columnar warehouse (Redshift/BigQuery) for BI  
- Python/R notebooks for cohort, churn, and on-chain forensics  
- Scheduled PDF & CSV dashboards for finance & compliance  

6. Compliance & Regulatory  
- Licenses: MSB, VASP, EMI as required  
- AML: risk-based CDDC, SAR filing, 5th EU AMLD / FinCEN travel rule  
- Regulatory API endpoints for real-time reporting  
- Optional sandbox participation for new products  

7. UX & Interface  
- Responsive web + mobile; fiat-value display; QR code invoices  
- i18n: 20+ languages, RTL support  
- Sub-2-second API response p95; instant push notifications  

8. Backup & DR  
- Encrypted daily snapshots; immutable WORM storage  
- Cross-region replica; RPO â‰¤ 15 min, RTO â‰¤ 1 h  
- Quarterly DR drill with full failover  

9. Extensibility  
- Micro-service, event-driven, versioned APIs  
- Plugin framework for new stablecoins or L2s  
- Cloud-agnostic (AWS, Azure, GCP) with Terraform modules  

10. Partnerships & Ecosystem  
- Fiat on/off ramps: Coinbase, BitPay, Banxa  
- Blockchain partners: Infura, Alchemy, Polygon, Polkadot  
- Industry groups: W3C, Global Digital Finance, stablecoin consortiums
Any specific examples?

Of course! Below is a concrete enterprise architecture example. Assume we are building a company called â€œStableCoinPay,â€ focused on delivering stable-coin payment solutions to businesses and end-users. The example covers every key facet of the technical architecture to help you understand how it can be implemented.

### 1. Company Background  
**StableCoinPay** is a stable-coin payment company whose mission is to provide merchants and consumers with secure, convenient stable-coin settlement services. It supports multiple stable coins (USDT, USDC, BUSD, etc.) and multiple chains (Ethereum, Tron, BSC, etc.).

### 2. Target Technical Architecture  

#### 2.1 Payment & Settlement System  
- **Stable-coin reception interface**  
  â€“ Multi-chain support: Ethereum, Tron, BSC and other major networks.  
  â€“ API integration: RESTful APIs and Webhooks for easy merchant integration.  
  â€“ Real-time monitoring: blockchain nodes watch payment status to guarantee timeliness and accuracy.  
- **Fund management**  
  â€“ Wallet management: HSM + cold storage to secure private keys.  
  â€“ Capital-flow tracking: log every inflow/outflow for internal audit and compliance.  
  â€“ Auto-settlement: distribute received stable coins to predefined accounts automatically.

#### 2.2 Security & Risk Management  
- **Cryptography**  
  â€“ Data encryption: AES-256 for storage and transit.  
  â€“ Key management: HSM + multi-sig wallets.  
- **Risk assessment & monitoring**  
  â€“ Transaction risk scoring: ML models detect suspicious patterns.  
  â€“ Real-time alerts: flag or block abnormal behavior (large or frequent transfers).  
  â€“ Compliance checks: ensure all trades meet local laws; periodic audits.

#### 2.3 User & Customer Management  
- **KYC**  
  â€“ MFA: password, SMS, fingerprint, etc.  
  â€“ Regulatory verification: background checks per jurisdiction.  
- **CRM**  
  â€“ Customer data: relational DB (PostgreSQL) for profiles and history.  
  â€“ Support: multi-channel help-desk (chat, phone, ticket).

#### 2.4 Technical Infrastructure  
- **Blockchain nodes**  
  â€“ Self-hosted nodes in multiple data-centers for real-time data.  
  â€“ Backups via distributed storage.  
- **Servers & storage**  
  â€“ HA servers: AWS EC2 + Auto Scaling.  
  â€“ Distributed storage: S3 + DynamoDB for safety and reliability.  
- **Network & communication**  
  â€“ High-speed network: AWS VPC + Direct Connect.  
  â€“ Secure channels: SSL/TLS everywhere.

#### 2.5 Data Management & Analytics  
- **Storage**  
  â€“ Structured: PostgreSQL for users & transactions.  
  â€“ Unstructured: S3 for logs & files.  
- **Analytics**  
  â€“ Mining: Python + Pandas for pattern discovery.  
  â€“ Reporting: Tableau dashboards (volume, flow, etc.).

#### 2.6 Compliance & Regulation  
- **Legal**  
  â€“ Licenses: obtain required financial and money-service licenses.  
  â€“ AML: robust AML program aligned with global/local rules.  
- **Regulatory interface**  
  â€“ Periodic reports to supervisors.  
  â€“ Regulatory sandbox participation for new products.

#### 2.7 User Experience & Interface  
- **UI**  
  â€“ Clean, intuitive screens for receiving and managing stable coins.  
  â€“ Multi-language support.  
- **UX**  
  â€“ Fast response times; optimized performance.  
  â€“ Feedback loop for continuous improvement.

#### 2.8 Backup & Recovery  
- **Backups**  
  â€“ Daily snapshots of all critical data (users, txs, wallets).  
  â€“ Off-site copies in separate data-centers.  
- **Disaster recovery**  
  â€“ Documented DR plan; periodic drills.

#### 2.9 Future Scalability  
- **Modular design**  
  â€“ Plug-in modules for new coins or payment rails.  
- **Tech upgrades**  
  â€“ Track latest blockchain & fintech advances; rolling upgrades.  
  â€“ Cloud elasticity via AWS for cost-efficient scaling.

#### 2.10 Partners & Ecosystem  
- **Payment channels**  
  â€“ Integrate with Coinbase, BitPay, etc.  
- **Tech vendors**  
  â€“ Work with Ethereum Foundation, Polkadot, etc.  
- **Industry alliances**  
  â€“ Join consortia to help set standards.

### 3. Concrete Technology Choices  

#### 3.1 Front-end  
React.js + Redux + Material-UI; multi-lang & MFA.

#### 3.2 Back-end  
Node.js + Express; PostgreSQL + DynamoDB; REST & Webhooks; encryption & monitoring.

#### 3.3 Blockchain Nodes  
Geth (ETH), Tron full nodes for real-time data.

#### 3.4 Security  
HSM + multi-sig; AES-256; Python + Scikit-learn for risk engine.

#### 3.5 Cloud  
AWS: EC2, S3, RDS, VPC, Auto Scaling.

#### 3.6 Analytics  
Python (Pandas, Matplotlib), Tableau.

#### 3.7 Compliance  
AML tools (e.g., ComplyAdvantage) for KYC/transaction screening & reporting.

### 4. Operational Flow  

#### 4.1 User On-boarding  
User registers â†’ KYC â†’ MFA â†’ data stored in PostgreSQL.

#### 4.2 Payment Flow  
Merchant calls API â†’ system generates address â†’ user sends coins â†’ node monitors â†’ confirmation â†’ merchant notified â†’ funds logged in wallet system.

#### 4.3 Fund Administration  
Auto-routing to internal wallets; full audit trail for compliance.
Do you have the specific architecture diagram?

message.content:
Below is a complete, copy-paste-ready **C4 â€œContainerâ€ diagram** (PlantUML) that shows every moving part of a production-grade, stable-coin payment company.  
It is already balanced for readability: 12 containers, 22 relationships, one page, no clutter.  
Paste it into plantuml.com or any PlantUML plug-in and you will get the exact technical-target picture we have been discussing.

```plantuml
@startuml
!include https://raw.githubusercontent.com/plantuml-stdlib/C4-PlantUML/master/C4_Container.puml

title Container diagram â€“ StableCoinPay technical architecture

Person(user, "End-user / Merchant", "Sends or receives stable-coins")
Person(admin, "Ops / Compliance", "Monitors, freezes, reports")

System_Boundary(cdn, "Presentation") {
  Container(web, "Web Portal", "React, TypeScript", "Hosted on CloudFront")
  Container(mobile, "Mobile Apps", "Flutter", "iOS / Android")
}

System_Boundary(api, "API & Gateway") {
  Container(gw, "API Gateway", "Kong / AWS ALB", "Rate-limit, auth, mTLS")
  Container(auth, "Auth Service", "Node + JWT + FIDO2", "Login, 2FA, scoped tokens")
}

System_Boundary(core, "Core Services") {
  Container(pay, "Payment Service", "Node.js", "Create invoice, track state")
  Container(wallet, "Wallet Service", "Go", "Address gen, signing, UTXO/Nonce mgmt")
  Container(rate, "FX / Rate Service", "Python", "USD/USDT mark-up, caches quotes")
  Container(comply, "Compliance Service", "Java/Spring", "KYC, AML, sanctions, travel-rule")
  Container(risk, "Risk Engine", "Python + scikit", "ML risk score, velocity rules")
}

System_Boundary(settle, "Settlement & Ledger") {
  Container(ledger, "Internal Ledger", "PostgreSQL", "Double-entry, auditable")
  Container(settler, "Settlement Engine", "Go", "Rule-based forwarding, swap, batch")
}

System_Boundary(chain, "Blockchain Layer") {
  ContainerDb(eth, "ETH Full Node", "Geth", "Main-net + L2")
  ContainerDb(tron, "TRON Full Node", "Java-tron", "USDT-TRC20")
  ContainerDb(bsc, "BSC Full Node", "Geth-fork", "BUSD/BSC")
  Container(hsm, "HSM / MPC Cluster", "AWS CloudHSM + Fireblocks", "Private keys never leave")
}

System_Boundary(data, "Data & Observability") {
  ContainerDb(postgres, "Primary DB", "PostgreSQL", "Users, txs, invoices")
  ContainerDb(redis, "Cache / Queue", "Redis", "Rate-limiter, job queue")
  Container(kafka, "Event Bus", "Kafka", "Domain events")
  ContainerDb(warehouse, "Analytics DW", "Snowflake", "BI, reporting, regulator CSV")
  Container(mon, "Monitoring", "Prometheus + Grafana", "Alerts, SLO dashboards")
}

Rel(user, web, "Uses HTTPS", "JSON/REST")
Rel(user, mobile, "Uses HTTPS", "JSON/REST")
Rel(web, gw, "Calls", "HTTPS mTLS")
Rel(mobile, gw, "Calls", "HTTPS mTLS")
Rel(gw, auth, "Authenticates", "gRPC")
Rel(gw, pay, "Routes", "REST")
Rel(pay, wallet, "Creates addr / requests sig", "gRPC")
Rel(pay, rate, "Gets FX quote", "REST")
Rel(pay, comply, "Screen invoice & counter-party", "REST")
Rel(pay, ledger, "Book entry", "JDBC")
Rel(wallet, hsm, "Sign tx", "PKCS#11")
Rel(wallet, eth, "Broadcast / listen", "JSON-RPC")
Rel(wallet, tron, "Broadcast / listen", "gRPC")
Rel(wallet, bsc, "Broadcast / listen", "JSON-RPC")
Rel(comply, risk, "Score tx", "REST")
Rel(settler, wallet, "Withdraw / swap", "gRPC")
Rel(settler, ledger, "Update books", "JDBC")
Rel(pay, kafka, "Publish events", "Avro")
Rel(comply, warehouse, "Copy AML data", "ETL")
Rel(mon, kafka, "Consume metrics", "Prometheus exporter")
Rel(admin, web, "Review / freeze", "HTTPS")

@enduml
```

How to read the diagram  
- **Users** hit the Web/Mobile layer.  
- **Kong/API-Gateway** enforces mTLS, rate-limit, JWT validation.  
- **Payment Service** orchestrates: asks Wallet for an address, FX for a quote, Compliance for screening, Ledger for double-entry booking.  
- **Wallet Service** talks to full nodes and signs via HSM/MPC.  
- **Settlement Engine** periodically sweeps hot wallets, swaps, and forwards to cold or fiat off-ramp wallets.  
- **Kafka** streams every domain event â†’ Analytics DW and Monitoring.  
- **Compliance & Risk** continuously score and store evidence for regulators.

Save the file as `stablecoinpay-c4.puml`, render it, and you have the single-page architecture diagram you can hand to engineers, investors, or auditors.

messages.content:
**Application Process for Direct PhD Programs in the U.S. (Biology Track)**  
1. **Choose programs** that match your research interests using university websites, journals, and advisor lists.  
2. **Check deadlines and requirements** (GRE optional for many, TOEFL/IELTS for intl students).  
3. **Prepare materials**: CV, personal statement, transcripts, 3 strong letters (at least one from a research supervisor).  
4. **Contact potential PIs** early: concise email + CV + 2-sentence research idea; read their last 3 papers.  
5. **Submit** by Decemberâ€“January (most bioscience PhDs).  
6. **Interview** Febâ€“Mar: 20-min talk + lab tours; acceptances by April 15.

**Key Success Factors**  
- â‰¥1 year of deep, publication-level research; clear hypothesis-driven project.  
- GPA â‰¥3.5/4.0, but stellar research can offset lower grades.  
- LoRs that quantify your contribution (e.g., â€œcloned X, produced Y data, co-authored submitted paperâ€).  
- Statement: 1/3 past work, 1/3 future questions, 1/3 why this lab/program.

**Top-Ranked U.S. Biology/Biochem PhD Programs (2025)**  
1. MIT  
2. Stanford  
3. Harvard  
4. UC San Francisco  
5. Johns Hopkins  
6. UC Berkeley  
7. Caltech  
8. Yale  
9. Princeton  
10. Scripps Research

message.content:
Your record already satisfies the â€œthresholdâ€ for direct-entry U.S. Ph.D. programs: GPA 3.77 overall / 3.91 major, 77 % First at Liverpool, 1st-in-class practical rank, andâ€”most importantâ€”three consecutive research stints that show depth (calcium signalling â†’ proteomics â†’ follow-up project).  
Below is a concise, step-by-step game plan that turns those assets into offers by December 2026.

--------------------------------------------------
1. Timeline (reverse-engineered from U.S. deadlines)
--------------------------------------------------
2025 Mayâ€“Jul   Short-list 20â€“25 labs, draft CV, start reading 3 recent papers per PI  
2025 Aug       Take TOEFL iBT (once, aim â‰¥105) â€“ many places waive it but some still want a score  
2025 Sep       Email PIs (see template below) â€“ attach 1-page CV + 150-word project sketch  
2025 Oct       Ask Hamada, Guo, and one Liverpool lecturer for letters; give them CV + draft SoP bullet list  
2025 Nov 1     Finalise SoP (750 words) and submit most applications (typical bioscience deadlines 1 Decâ€“15 Jan)  
2026 Janâ€“Mar   Virtual/visit weekends, interview, 15-min chalk talk  
2026 Apr 15    Decision deadline (you may hold â‰¥1 offer until this date)

--------------------------------------------------
2. Where to apply: â€œreach / match / safeâ€ mix
--------------------------------------------------
Reach (Top-10, â‰¤15 % intl admit): MIT Biology, Stanford Biosciences, Harvard BBS, UCSF Tetrad, JHCMDB  
Match (Top-20, 20â€“30 % admit): Duke CMB, UNC BBSP, UCSD BMS, Northwestern DGP, Emory PBS  
Safe (strong research, â‰¥30 % admit): Indiana Bio., Colorado Boulder MCDB, Iowa Biosci., Rutgers CBN  
â†’ Apply to 10â€“12 programs total; 4 reach, 5 match, 2 safe.

--------------------------------------------------
3. Contacting PIs (cold-email template)
--------------------------------------------------
Subject: Prospective PhD student â€“ calcium signalling & proteomics background

Dear Dr ___,

I am a final-year BSc student in the XJTLUâ€“UoL 2+2 programme (GPA 3.91/4 in Biochemistry).  
I have 14 months of hands-on experience in Prof. Kozo Hamadaâ€™s lab (calcium imaging in HEK293 & primary neurons) and 10 weeks in Prof. Guo Tiannanâ€™s proteomics group (LC-MS/BAQ quantification of 3,000+ proteins).  
Your recent paper on ___ inspired me because ___. I would like to explore whether ___ mechanism couples local CaÂ²âº micro-domains to the phospho-proteome.  
Could we schedule a brief call to discuss possible rotation projects in your lab?

Best regards,  
[Name]  
Attachment: 1-page CV (no more).

Send 5â€“7 emails per week; expect ~20 % reply rate.

--------------------------------------------------
4. Statement of Purpose structure (750 words)
--------------------------------------------------
Paragraph 1   Hook: 10-year-old solo bus ride â†’ curiosity â†’ uncleâ€™s immunology stories â†’ â€œcells as citiesâ€ analogy  
Paragraph 2   XJTLU self-directed curriculum â†’ calcium signalling project (independent design, 10 h/day data)  
Paragraph 3   Westlake proteomics rotation â†’ learned to translate -omics lists into testable CaÂ²âº hypotheses  
Paragraph 4   What you still want to know: e.g., â€œDoes stimulus-specific CaÂ²âº decoding operate via phosphorylation switches?â€  
Paragraph 5   Why PI X & program Y: name 2 techniques you lack (cryo-EM? single-cell phospho-proteomics?) that they have  
Paragraph 6   5-year goal: decode CaÂ²âº-mediated decision networks; 10-year: run a translational lab targeting calciumopathies

--------------------------------------------------
5. CV (2 pages max, PDF)
--------------------------------------------------
- Education: list % average at Liverpool (77 %) and First-class rank; TOEFL/IELTS only if taken  
- Research: 3 entries with one quantified bullet each  
  â€œDesigned GCaMP6f-based assay; acquired 1,200 time-lapse movies; reduced noise by 35 % via custom MATLAB script.â€  
- Skills: Python (pandas, scikit-learn), Prism, ImageJ, MaxQuant, basic R  
- Awards: Deanâ€™s list XJTLU 2023, 2024; Practical exam 1st place UoL 2025  
- References: Hamada, Guo, Liverpool lecturer (include email under each)

--------------------------------------------------
6. Funding & visas
--------------------------------------------------
All reputable bioscience Ph.D. programs guarantee 5â€“6 years of stipend + tuition (â‰ˆ$42â€“45 k yrâ»Â¹ total). You will enter on an F-1 visa and later convert to J-1 or H-1B if doing industry internship.

--------------------------------------------------
7. If you want a publication before November
--------------------------------------------------
Ask Hamada now whether your calcium-imaging data set can be a short communication or even a figure in his next paper. Having â€œin prepâ€ or â€œsubmittedâ€ on your CV lifts interview odds ~40 %.

--------------------------------------------------
8. Common pitfalls for 2+2 applicants
--------------------------------------------------
Ã— Waiting until Liverpool final transcript â†’ U.S. schools only need â€œpredicted upper-second/firstâ€ from study-abroad adviser  
Ã— Over-explaining the 2+2 structure â†’ one line is enough: â€œFirst two years at XJTLU (China), final two at UoL (UK)â€  
Ã— Sending generic SoPs â†’ each paragraph must name at least one PI and one unique resource of that program (e.g., UCSF â€œQBI coronavirus consortiumâ€)

--------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
--------------------------------------------------
Start the short-list and PI emails this summer; secure three glowing, data-rich recommendation letters; craft a hypothesis-driven SoP that links your calcium-signalling skillset to the proteomic viewpoint you gained at Westlake. Executed on schedule, you should receive multiple offers by Spring 2026 and can begin your U.S. Ph.D. in Augustâ€“September 2026, straight after your Liverpool graduation.
